For one minute, put aside the fact that rank and file lawmakers like myself had less than 24 hours to review the 2,313 bill and ask yourself: are massive spending bills filled with special interest carve outs the way you want your government to legislate? https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-bipartisan-spending-party-11577053425 …

The dirty secret is that many House members like this arrangement because it prevents them from having to cast tough votes. I wrote about that last year: https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2018/11/gallagher-congress/575689/ …
Regardless of where you stand on either of these two decisions, you should demand your lawmakers at least debate proposals like these, not vote on them with less than 24 hours notice.

And while any common sense individual would presume a government spending bill would only direct spending, this bill does more than that. It includes major policy changes. For example, this bill:
 
-)Reauthorized the Export-Import Bank for 7 years
 
-)Raised the smoking age to 21

That’s not all. Speaker Pelosi also made sure to include federal loans for the Presidio Trust -- which maintains a park in her district -- in the amount of $10 million for an earmark to fund park maintenance and restoration. 
  https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/House-sinks-Hetch-Hetchy-boating-proposal-14915923.php …

For example, while there were a number of last minute tax provisions jockeying to be the most ridiculous addition, provisions about thoroughbred racehorse and motorsports entertainment complex depreciation were at the head of the pack.

While I'm under no illusions that these bills represent a comprehensive solution, they do form the foundation of a new maximum pressure campaign against the cartels. Security in our own backyard is not something we can ever take for granted. It's time to get to work.

This week, I will be introducing legislation to establish Border Enforcement Security Task Forces that will be specifically tasked with investigating transnational criminal arms smuggling rings across the border into Mexico.

Many Americans might not realize this, but we have a role to play as well. Unfortunately, many of the guns that arm the cartels come from the United States. Yet CBP is understandably focused on searching inbound traffic into the country, so outbound flows are largely unscreened

Next, to increase direct pressure, I introduced legislation to establish a Significant Transnational Criminal Organization designation that allows the President to impose sanctions on the cartels similar to those imposed on Foreign Terrorist Organizations. https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/gallagher-colleagues-introduce-bill-impose-sanctions-drug-cartels …

On International Anti-Corruption Day last week, I introduced the Supporting Mexico Against Corruption Act, which tasks the admin with imposing Magnitsky sanctions on Mexican officials it has credible evidence have engaged in significant corruption. https://gallagher.house.gov/media/press-releases/gallagher-introduces-bill-support-mexico-s-anti-corruption-campaign …

The U.S. government has powerful authorities to assist the Mexican government in combating corruption, including Global Magnitsky sanctions. Yet in more than two years, we've only imposed Magnitsky sanctions on one Mexican government official for aiding these cartels.

The first step is helping the Mexican government combat the corruption that gives these criminals safe harbor. Just last week, the former head of Mexican public security was arrested for allegedly accepting millions of dollars in bribes from the cartels. https://www.npr.org/2019/12/10/786792134/former-top-mexican-security-official-arrested-on-cocaine-trafficking-charges …

While the FBI is full of hardworking, patriotic employees, the mistakes detailed in this report force us to consider making broader changes. If these errors could happen when those involved knew they would be watched closely, they could happen to anyone.

FISA abuse matters. This surveillance is one of the most intrusive interactions Americans can experience with law enforcement, and if abused, it undermines the rule of law and trust. We are not the Chinese Communist Party and must reject mass arbitrary surveillance.

In one instance, an FBI lawyer misled the FISA court by altering an email from another government agency that could have cast doubt on the advisability of a FISA renewal application before the court. The altered email was used as evidence to renew the warrant.

THREAD➡️Despite claims by James Comey & some in the media, the IG report doesn't exonerate the FBI. Instead, it shows that leaders entrusted with our national security & rule of law failed to follow established procedures when the stakes were highest. This should trouble us all.
